courses.title: Physics Orientation
courses.description: Guest lectures will describe career opportunities in physics; the role physicists play in education, government, and industrial laboratories; and programs available to physics majors.

courses.title: Introductory Physics I
courses.description: An introductory course which will include mechanics (kinematics, dynamics, work and energy, momentum and collisions, and rotational motion and statics), and will include thermodynamics and waves. Elementary algebra and trigonometry will be used.

courses.title: The Solar System
courses.description: This course covers Ancient and Renaissance astronomy, gravity, sky phenomena, telescopes, and the solar system.

courses.title: Stars, Galaxies, and the Universe
courses.description: This course covers optics, telescopes, stellar characteristics and evolution, galaxies, the universe, and the big bang.  Physics topics include mechanics, optics, atomic physics, nuclear physics, and relativity.

courses.title: Physics Of Music
courses.description: An introduction to the physical principles underlying the production, transmission, and detection of musical sounds.

courses.title: Introduction to Astrophysics
courses.description: This course provides an overview of modern astrophysics including stars, galaxies, black holes and other dense stellar remnants, and the physics of the expanding Universe.

courses.title: Principles of Physics I
courses.description: An introductory course which will include mechanics (kinematics, dynamics, work and energy, momentum and collisions, and rotational motion and statics), and may also include oscillations and computational methods. This is a calculus-based course.

courses.title: Principles of Physics II
courses.description: An introductory course which will include electrostatics, electric current and circuits,  electromagnetism, and may also include light and computational methods. This is a calculus-based course.

courses.title: Introduction to Modern Physics
courses.description: A survey of twentieth century physics.  Developments of several branches of physics up to their present frontiers, including historical and philosophical perspectives.

courses.title: Honors Physics I
courses.description: Parallels introductory Physics I (PHYS 2211). Some topics treated in more depth or more extensively. A rigorous physics foundation requiring demonstrated competence in mathematics.

courses.title: Honors Physics II
courses.description: Parallels introductory Physics II (PHYS 2212). Some topics treated in more depth or more extensively.  No modern physics content. A rigorous physics foundation requiring demonstrated competence in mathematics.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship

courses.title: Physics of the Weather
courses.description: An introductory treatment applying basic physical laws to understanding weather phenomena.  Crosslisted with EAS 2750.

courses.title: Stars and Planets
courses.description: This course covers stellar atmospheres, interiors and evolution, as well as the formation and physical properties of planetary systems.

courses.title: Computational Physics
courses.description: Introduction to computational methods in physics, including numerical integration and solving ordinary and partial differential equations. Applications to a range of physics problems are presented.

courses.title: Electrostatics and Magnetostatics
courses.description: First of two courses on the physics of electromagnetism. Topics include Coulomb's Law, Ampere's Law, scalar and vector potentials,Laplace's equation and electric and magnetic fields in matter.

courses.title: Electrodynamics
courses.description: Second of two courses on the physics of electromagnetism. Topics include time-dependent phenomena including Faraday's Law, the Maxwell equations, electromagnetic radiation, and electromagnetic waves.

courses.title: Thermodynamics
courses.description: Introduction to the basic concepts of thermodynamics. Thermodynamic laws will be developed with an emphasis on the macroscopic point of view.  Applications of the basic principles will be considered briefly.

courses.title: Quantum Mechanics I
courses.description: First of two courses that develop the principles of quantum mechanics.  Topics include the state vector concept. Heisenberg and Schrodinger pictures, uncertainty relations, and exact solvable models in one dimension.

courses.title: Mathematical Physics
courses.description: A review of the mathematical techniques required for the description of physical systems encountered in mechanics, electromagnetism, thermal physics, and quantum mechanics.

courses.title: Classical Mechanics I
courses.description: Fundamental topics in classical mechanics including oscillations, planetary motion, and Lagrangian and Hamiltonian techniques.

courses.title: Classical Mechanics II
courses.description: A continuation of PHYS 3201. Topics include many body mechanics, rotation of rigid bodies and collisions.

courses.title: Living Systems Laboratory
courses.description: Introduces students to the field of Physics of Living Systems via experimental studies of diverse biological systems, including molecular nanomachines, organism locomotion and ecological dynamics.

courses.title: Modern Optics Laboratory
courses.description: Measurement of parameters of optical surfaces, lenses, and systems using a variety of modern optics techniques.

courses.title: Electronics I
courses.description: A first course in both theoretical and applied electronics that is based on a thorough grounding in circuit as well as device physics.

courses.title: Astronomy & Astrophysics Lab
courses.description: An introduction to astronomical and astrophysical data reduction and analysis, drawing on instrumentation and telescopes from across modern astrophysics.

courses.title: Optics I
courses.description: Optics principles, including waves, reflection, refraction, absorption, scattering, group velocity, lasers, polarization geometrical optics, the Fourier transform, coherence, interference, and diffraction.

courses.title: Principles of the Physics of Living Systems
courses.description: Hands-on lecture/lab undergraduate survey course enabling discovery of principles of Physics of Living Systems across scales.

courses.title: Statistical Mechanics
courses.description: The statistical basis of thermodynamics is developed. Topics include entropy and the second law, partition functions and free energy, systems of variable particle number, and quantum statistics.

courses.title: Quantum Mechanics II
courses.description: Second of two courses that develop the principles of quantum mechanics.  Topics include angular momentum, hydrogen atom, variation methods, perturbation theory, matter-radiation interactions, identical particles.

courses.title: Relativity
courses.description: The course provides an introduction to the special and general theories of relativity that govern gravitational physics including experimental tests, astrophysical applications, black holes and gravitational waves.

courses.title: Electronics II
courses.description: A course in electronic instrumentation with an emphasis on signal processing, both analog and digital, and computer interfacing.

courses.title: Cosmology and Galaxies
courses.description: Modern cosmology of the universe, with the emphasis on the origin and evolution of galaxies and clusters of galaxies, inflation, the cosmic microwave background, dark matter and dark energy.

courses.title: Neurophysics
courses.description: Hands-on lecture/lab undergraduate course connecting theory and experiment to understand principles of neuron, brain, and heart function. Draws upon nonlinear dynamics, basic electrostatics, and electrophysiology.

courses.title: Biophysics
courses.description: Physical principles applied to molecular and cellular biology. Topics include chemiosmosis, self-assembly, protein biosynthesis, and the mechanisms of muscle and nerve function.

courses.title: Quantum Technologies
courses.description: Introduction to quantum information systems, with an emphasis on the physics (superconductivity, ion and atom trapping, quantum dots) behind the leading candidate platforms.

courses.title: Atomic Physics
courses.description: Course provides an introduction to the fundamentals of atomic physics, the structure of atoms, and their interaction with static and radiation fields.

courses.title: Solid-state Physics
courses.description: A first course in the physics of crystalline solids.  Core topics include crystal lattices, diffraction, bonding, elastic properties, band theory, as well as others.

courses.title: Nuclei, Particles, and Fields
courses.description: An introduction to nuclear and subnuclear systems. Topics include nuclear models, radioactive decay, nuclear reactions, quarks, accelerators, reactors, and stellar nucleosynthesis.

courses.title: Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos
courses.description: A modern introduction to nonlinear phenomena.  Topics include driven oscillators, entrainment, bifurcation, fractals, and control of chaos.  Examples are drawn from physical systems.

courses.title: Cell and Tissue Biophysics
courses.description: The physical principles that govern cell biological phenomena such as cell sensing, cell mechanics, migration, phase separation in cells, and bacterial navigation.

courses.title: Advanced Laboratory I
courses.description: Experiments are conducted that demonstrate basic principles from various fields of physics.  An emphasis is placed on contemporary concepts in modern physics.

courses.title: Advanced Laboratory II
courses.description: A continuation of PHYS 4321.  Experiments are conducted that demonstrate basic principles from various fields of physics. An emphasis is placed on contemporary concepts in modern physics.

courses.title: Theoretical Astrophysics
courses.description: Theoretical investigation of astrophysical objects and processes, with an emphasis on the interstellar medium, extragalactic astrophysics, gas dynamics, and radiative transfer, and radiation processes.

courses.title: Introduction to Continuum Physics
courses.description: A modern introduction to continuum physics.  Topics include elastic theory, dislocations and waves, fluid mechanics and dynamics, and instabilities in fluids.

courses.title: Senior Seminar I
courses.description: Representative research programs in the School are described by advanced graduate students, post-doctoral fellows and faculty members.

courses.title: Senior Seminar II
courses.description: Representative research programs in the school are described by advanced graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, and faculty members.

courses.title: Professional Development
courses.description: Professional development for physics undergraduate students. Topics include writing a resume, writing a proposal, applying for jobs, and choosing a graduate school.

courses.title: Scientific Communication
courses.description: Scientific communication for physics undergraduate students, with a particular focus on the development of oral communication skills.

courses.title: Introductory Diffraction Studies
courses.description: Introductory theory and practice of x-ray and neutron diffraction techniques, including single crystals and powders.  Laboratory work is strongly correlated with principles developed in the lectures.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Estimation and Approximation in Physics
courses.description: Applications of order-of-magnitude estimates, dimensional analysis, scaling arguments, and perturbation theory in different areas of physics.

courses.title: Physics of Cognition
courses.description: The course delves into perception, memory, and learning through physical principles. Students study cognition's physical basis, modern neural recording, and data interpretation.

courses.title: Laser Theory and Applications
courses.description: Provides an introduction to the theory and applications of laser principles and related instrumentation. Emphasis is on the fundamental principles underlying laser action. Crosslisted with ECE 4751.

courses.title: Quantum Information and Quantum Computing
courses.description: Introduction to quantum computing and quantum information theory, formalism of quantum mechanics, quantum gates, algorithms, measurements, coding, and information.  Physical realizations and experiments. Crosslisted with MATH 4782.

courses.title: Classical Mechanics I
courses.description: Newtonian mechanics, Hamilton's variational principle, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics, central forces, rigid body motion, and small oscillations.

courses.title: Electromagnetism
courses.description: An advanced treatment of electromagnetism. Topics include boundary value problems in electrostatics and magnetostatics, Maxwell’s equations, and radiation from charged particles.

courses.title: Electromagnetism II
courses.description: Theory of generation of electromagnetic waves, their propagation, scattering, and diffraction.  Covariant formulation of electrodynamics and application to radiation from charged particles.

courses.title: Quantum Mechanics I
courses.description: An axiomatic development of quantum mechanics. Topics include linear vector spaces, linear operators, infinitesimal transformations, function space, representation and transformation groups.

courses.title: Quantum Mechanics II
courses.description: Applications of quantum mechanics.  Topics include systems with spin and angular momentum, atomic structure, time-dependent phenomena, scattering, and various methods of modeling and approximations.

courses.title: Statistical Mechanics I
courses.description: Equilibrium statistical mechanics for closed and open systems. Probability distribution for classical and quantum systems.  Partition functions and associated thermodynamical potentials.

courses.title: Mathematical Methods of Physics I
courses.description: First of two courses on mathematical methods used in classical mechanics, electromagnetism, quantum mechanics, and statistical physics.  Topics include complex analysis, vectors and matrices, and Sturm-Liouville theory.

courses.title: Soft Matter Physics
courses.description: Introduction to the properties and physical description of soft matter systems including polymers, colloids and interfaces.

courses.title: Condensed Matter Physics I
courses.description: Introduction to condensed matter physics. Crystal structure, electronic and thermal properties, response to external electric and magnetic fields.

courses.title: Condensed Matter Physics II
courses.description: Collective and many-electron properties in condensed matter systems.  Topics include second quantization, magnetism, phase transitions, and superconductivity.

courses.title: Astrophysical Radiative Processes
courses.description: Radiation emission, absorption and scattering processes in astrophysical systems, including bremsstrahlung and synchrotron radiation. An introduction to radiation transfer. Determining physical quantities from observations.

courses.title: Biophysics
courses.description: Introduction to physical concepts connect to the workings of biological systems at a molecular level. Topics include polymer theory of proteins, diffusion, and bioelectricity.

courses.title: Computational Physics
courses.description: Applications of numerical methods and computer programming to condensed matter; astrophysical hydrodynamics, gravitational physics, black holes and cosmology.

courses.title: Data Science for Physicists
courses.description: Introduction to probability theory, classical statistics and machine learning, and their application to physics.

courses.title: Atomic Physics I
courses.description: This course provides a detailed description of atomic structures and interactions.  It contains applications of advanced quantum mechanics to problems in modern atomic physics.

courses.title: Atomic Physics II
courses.description: This course will provide detailed descriptions of non-relativistic atomic/molecular scattering/reaction processes.

courses.title: Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos
courses.description: A modern introduction to nonlinear phenomena. Topics include driven oscillators, entrainment, bifurcation, fractals, and control of chaos. Examples are drawn from physical systems.

courses.title: Ultrafast Optics
courses.description: A modern introduction to ultrafast optical phenomena. Topics include the generation, amplification, measurement, nonlinear optics, propagation, focusing, shaping and applications of ultrashort laser pulses.

courses.title: Estimation and Approximation in Physics
courses.description: Applications of order-of-magnitude estimates, dimensional analysis, scaling arguments, and perturbation theory in different areas of physics.

courses.title: Foundations of Quantitative Biosciences
courses.description: Introduction to quantitative methods and logic that enable key advances in understanding living systems, spanning molecules, cells, organisms, and biomes.

courses.title: Optoelectronics: Materials, Processes, Devices
courses.description: Optoelectronic materials, physical processes, and devices. Includes compound semiconductor materials, excitation, recombination, gain, and modulation processes, and devices such as emitters, detectors, and modulators. Crosslisted with ECE 6771.

courses.title: Grant Writing and Navigating the Scientific Landscape
courses.description: An introduction to the skills of a professional scientist both within academia and beyond, focusing on preparing grants and proposals, scientific communication and career preparation.

courses.title: Physics GTA Preparation
courses.description: An introduction to learner-centered teaching methods and best practices for new physics graduate teaching assistants.

courses.title: Statistical Mechanics II
courses.description: Principles of nonequilibrium statistical mechanics, both classical and quantal.  Emphasis is on the dynamics of fluctuations, their measurement, and their relationship to transport properties.

courses.title: Introduction to Relativity
courses.description: The theory of gravity, describing how matter curves spacetime and spacetime guides matter, with its experimental and theoretical applications.

courses.title: Cosmology & Galaxies
courses.description: Overview of the relevant physics that govern cosmological processes, and galaxy formation and evolution. Topics include inflation, gravitational collapse, large-scale clustering, and galaxy mergers.

courses.title: High-Energy Astrophysics
courses.description: Introduction to high-energy astrophysical processes and environments, including astrophysical fluid dynamics (e.g., shocks and blast waves), accretion onto compact objects, and clusters of galaxies.

courses.title: Many-Particle Quantum Mechanics
courses.description: Quantum mechanics of interacting Fermi and Bose particles. Topics include second quantization, diagrammatic purturbation theory, variational methods, and path integrals.

courses.title: Group Theory and Quantum Mechanics
courses.description: Foundations of group representation theory with applications in atomic, molecular, nuclear, and solid state physics.

courses.title: Quantum Field Theory
courses.description: Introduction to quantum field theory, with an emphasis in quantum electrodynamics.  Second quantization, Dirac equation, Feynman diagrams, quantum electrodynamics, electro-weak interactions.

courses.title: Quantum Optics I
courses.description: Basic course on the interaction of light with matter, based on quantum theory.  Applications to the laser and to the study of coherence properties of light.

courses.title: Quantum Optics II
courses.description: Advanced treatment of the interaction of light with matter using modern methods of open quantum systems.  Applications to current research.

courses.title: Nonlinear Hamiltonian Dynamics and Chaos
courses.description: A course on nonlinear dissipative dynamical systems, with an emphasis in aspects relevant to physicists.  Topics include bifurcation theory, attractors, renormalization group techniques, and pattern formation.

courses.title: Spatio-Temporal Dynamics and Pattern Formation
courses.description: A theoretical description of dynamics and pattern formation in physical, chemical and biological systems driven out of equilibrium. Topics include linear and weakly nonlinear analysis of patterns, bifurcation theory and amplitude equations.

courses.title: Robotics Professional Preparation
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Program introduction. Technical resume preparation. GT Robotics labs & resources.

courses.title: Robotics Professional Preparation 2
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Selecting and applying for Internship. Developing capstone project proposal. Public speaking practice and preparation.

courses.title: Robotics Professional Preparation 3
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Interview preparation & career search. Technical report writing and presentation.

courses.title: Seminar
courses.description: Representative research programs in the School are described by advanced graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, and faculty members. The experimental basis of physics is illustrated through accounts of great experiments of importance to contemporary research.

courses.title: Graduate Student Seminar
courses.description: Representative research programs in the School are described by advanced graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, and faculty members. The experimental basis of physics is illustrated through accounts of great experiments of importance to contemporary research.

courses.title: Robotics Internship
courses.description: Graduate Internship at a partner company, GTRI or a GT Robotics lab.

courses.title: Robotics Capstone Project
courses.description: Teams or individuals apply the knowledge and skills acquired throughout the MS program to a faculty supervised robotics project.
